really care about when it comes to mobile
gaming a first-person shooter and a great

1363.15.text: way to really show off the frame rate and general

1365.59.text: smoothness of the Nexus 5. At no point where I've been playing

1369.76.text:
this game have I seen any slowdown.
What I have seen is a

1373.61.text: vastly improved frame rate over previous devices, specifically over the Galaxy S4, the game

1380.55.text: just flies on here. Nexus 4 felt at times slightly janky. It would stall out in strange places

1389.79.text:
and the frame rate didn't feel like it was
consistent.

1393.01.text:
Here we have a very very consistent frame
rate and it just feels beautifully smooth

1398.92.text:
to the point where in my opinion it's now
actually playable where previously it wasn't

1406.04.text: always the most playable of games due to the frame rate dips etcetera.

1410.22.text:
Does feel like the Snapdragon processor is
really doing a great job here.

1416.78.text:
That was a very long range knife kill. Good
old Gameloft bug there that's when they work

1427.17.text: in our favour but anyway. But as you can see, Modern Combat no problems

1432.46.text: here. It looks fantastic. This is probably next to the Galaxy Note 3

1437.69.text:
the best way to play this particular game,
certainly if you're looking for really high

1442.20.text:
frame rates anyway.Absolutely glorious. Love
it!

1447.46.text:
Die, nondescript bad guy. Die! This is Riptide
GP2. This is obviously another really high

1454.18.text:
performance game that makes incredible use
of water effects and so on and so it's one

1459.65.text:
of those titles that is great for showing
off what your device can do.

1463.90.text: Now obviously, because it's a gyroscope game you're going to have to excuse me while it

1467.43.text:
tilts around the screen a little bit but the
frame rate not always as consistent as it

1472.90.text:
could be on here but a lot of it I put down
to being game developer issues more than anything

1477.57.text:
else.It is very difficult to simulate water
and speed like this on a mobile device and

1482.22.text:
so occasionally you will see it just dip out
a little bit, I shouldn't maybe be braking

1488.38.text:
into these corners but never mind.
It's not a deal breaker by any stretch of

1492.82.text:
the imagination because 99.99% of the time
the game is absolutely spot-on but there is

1497.93.text:
just the occasional dip in the frame rate.
Seems to be mostly when you're going round

1503.11.text:
kind of bends and that's to be expected as
the fill rate kind of goes up quite considerably

1508.51.text: at that point. But overall it's a beautiful looking game

1511.35.text: and it always has been and on the Nexus 5 works absolutely

1515.24.text: fine, no major problems,nice and good to look. Like I say, just the occasional bit of what

1520.52.text:
you can perceive as slowdown just the frames
dropping a little tiny bit but nothing major

1527.30.text: no major problems here at all. So let's talk about the software. Now with a Nexus

1532.58.text:
device, we don't get lots of bloatware, what
we do get is a lot of Googles apps and core

1536.16.text:
services fully  integrated into the device.
That starts now with a new launcher.

1541.00.text:
A launcher is fully integrated with Google
search and vice versa and so you can pull

1546.47.text: up a search from the home screen as you could always but now there are also voice commands

1551.88.text: which allow you to say OK Google. And the device will kick off Google Now and

1556.65.text: you can run your search query. Now I'm actually having some problems with it today. I installed

1561.04.text:
the Swiftkey keyboard last night and for some
reason my voice commands are not working,

1566.87.text: even though they should be and all my settings are perfect.

1569.33.text:
So I will just show you over here now how
that works and then come back and  we'll carry

1573.50.text:
on talking about the rest of the software.
OK Google, what's the weather like today?

1583.09.text:
Software wise, like I say, we get all of the
core Google experience.

1587.10.text: So, we have GMail, Google Plus, the new photos app which at some point is probably going

1593.34.text:
to replace the Google Gallery but not just
yet we now have Google Gallery and this photos

1598.76.text: app which is tied into Google+. Google Maps, the People or contacts list,

1604.16.text: Google Calendar, Google Keep, Drive, and YouTube. We also have Hangouts and a new phone dialler

1610.64.text:
as well. Now the phone dialler is again
fully integrated with the Google search system

1615.07.text: so you can search for contacts instead of providing huge numbers of contacts and a fairly ugly

1620.92.text:
interface now you can do everything via a
simple search query and the most used will

1625.77.text: appear at the bottom here with photos as necessary. There's a new phone dialler which is very

1631.18.text: nicely integrated and just looks awesome when it's popping up like that, and then you've

1635.76.text: got your options on the side here. All very nicely done. It's a beautiful design

1642.50.text: and it works very nicely. Now Hangouts has a major new feature that's

1648.27.text:
been added in. Which is now SMS integration
within Hangouts. So if one of your Hangouts contacts

1653.61.text:
sends you an SMS instead of it going into
the separate messaging app like it used to

1656.67.text: it all comes into Hangouts. Effectively Hangouts is your messaging client

1660.28.text: from now on. You also get Google Chrome which I think

1663.66.text:
has been updated to the latest Webkit build
or whatever, that Google are doing with Webkit

1668.17.text: these days and there's also the Google camera app and as I highlighted earlier in my review

1674.05.text: the camera app is atrocious and really Google should be ashamed that they even shipped it,

1680.00.text: it's so buggy. It makes their camera look weak when the camera

1683.39.text:
actually isn't that weak in my opinion. But the
app is very weak.

1686.88.text:
We also have access to Google play music,
movies and books and the play games app which

1692.50.text: is very nice by the way. Overall it's a great package of basic software.

1698.96.text:
If you only use Google Services it's absolutely
fine.If you happen to be tied into Samsung,

1703.05.text:
HTC Services already it's going to be a bit
of a retrograde step for you unfortunately.

1709.05.text:
But over all, the whole experience with the
Google Android 4.4 is very good. It's a very

1715.96.text:
fast operating system and not just because
of the upgraded hardware specs that the Nexus

1720.63.text: 5 offers. Overall, it's very tight and fluid. There's

1725.12.text:
none of this kind of stuttering or laggyness
that we've seen in other versions of Android.

1730.50.text: Now there is still the occasional stutter when you're installing something but that's

1735.51.text:
kind of par for the course. We see that on
absolutely every Android device out there

1739.68.text: and even iPhones, so you know, it's not something that I even really mark a device down for

1745.17.text:
anymore. It's just that the way software works
on these devices.

1749.01.text:
Trying to read and write data to the flash
memory simultaneously is going to cause a

1753.17.text: little bit of stutter. So overall, the software package is really

1757.71.text:
excellent. The Gallery app is OK, it's been
hanging around now for a little too long,

1762.28.text:
probably about time the photos app did kill
that off actually.

1765.34.text:
If you're interested in knowing how you get
into your widgets area because that's moved

1769.50.text:
now, you long press and that will then bring
up your home screen overlay. You can access

1775.11.text: your wallpapers, and your widgets and also your settings.

1777.42.text: So you go into widgets you've then got access to all of your widgets there and you can just

1781.59.text:
do a long press to drag them onto the home
screen. Long press, drag, drop. Easy as that.

1790.89.text:
In my opinion, Google have put together a
very good update to Android. 4.4 might not

1795.61.text:
be the revolution we were all hoping for but
what we came to expect might be Android 5

1801.20.text:
but it's a very good solid update and it's
good to see that there's still this progression

1805.16.text: at Google, the tweaking and fixing and making things faster and better. Overall each stage

1811.27.text: of Android has got better and better and better. I would say that I think they need to put

1816.47.text:
a little more time and effort into their camera
app and some of the other apps that you know,

1821.33.text:
are kind of go-to apps for most users and
if the experience isn't great it's not giving

1825.33.text: a great experience of hardware. But, you know, maybe Google will patch that

1830.22.text: over the next few weeks and things will improve quite considerably.

1834.46.text:
Let's talk about battery life because the
Nexus devices have not exactly been known

1838.48.text:
for brilliant batteries and this one has a
slightly smaller one than we've seen on the

1842.34.text:
S4 yet it's powering a similar size screen.
So far, I've found the battery life to be

1847.95.text: really excellent. Obviously I've been hammering the device pretty hard, playing games lots

1852.53.text:
of wifi installing apps and just generally
running the screen brightness full tilt and

1857.37.text: having it on most of the time. And I've found the battery's getting through

1860.62.text:
a full day with no problems whatsoever.
One of the things that's very interesting

1864.82.text:
about the battery life on the Nexus 5 is the
new DSP audio tunnelling I think it's called.

1872.18.text: And this is a feature that Qualcomm Snapdragon S 800 chip. What it basically does is it more

1878.54.text: efficiently works with the audio so when you're playing any audio over the device, beit headphones

1884.45.text: or from the speakers, it's consuming less power than it would normally do.

1889.07.text:
And they reckon this will extend the battery
life by about 30%. Certainly from what I'm

1893.50.text:
seeing from the device it is getting a very
good run out of that battery.

1897.54.text:
Even though it's powering up a lot of very
high end hardware. No problems here as far

1902.31.text: as I'm concerned with the battery. I am very pleased. What is my final

1905.50.text: verdict on the Nexus 5? Buy one. For the price point £300, $400 I think, you are not going

1913.75.text:
to get a better smartphone out there right
now. Certainly I don't think before Christmas.

1918.06.text:
The next big thing will probably be dropping
in January and February so if you're looking

1922.64.text:
for a smartphone this Christmas, if you don't
want the size of the Galaxy Note 3 then the

1927.92.text:
Nexus 5 is on your Christmas shopping list
for absolute definite.

1931.99.text: It's brilliant for gaming. It's great for music. It's got a fantastic display. The camera

1936.58.text: is better than any Nexus we've ever had before. The thing just flies, it is so fast it is

1942.82.text: unbelievable. And more importantly that display is just so crisp. Absolutely beautiful.

1948.41.text:
If there is one device you are thinking of
looking at this Christmas in amongst all the

1953.92.text:
other great smartphones on the market give
the Nexus 5 a look, borrow one off a friend,

1959.26.text:
go and see them in the shops whatever, but
you do need to see this device in person,

1963.15.text:
to really get a feel for how great it is in
the hand, how sharp that screen is and how

1967.92.text: absolutely powerful it is as well.
